title: How do we know? No directionality of light.
post:
“we have no solid reason for thinking the image represents reflected light on a man’s body”
Good point. Now I know it’s greatly frowned upon by some designated pro authentication gatekeeprs here, but dare we suggest that the light represented on the shroud is not reflected off the body because rather it came from the body? Imagine that — the shroud visually documents an exotic phenomenon predictable by both OT and NT texts and heavily hinted at in the very narrative surrounding the burial/resurrection of Christ where the shroud would have been during such an event! Hmm, that’s too obvious, let’s just call it a metaphor and quickly move on from this predetermined dead-end without looking deeper into it first!
For those who can suppress the emotional knee-jerk and want to scientifically investigate the possibility — is there some documented phenomenon in nature that could at the very least hint at light emitting from the human form? If so, could it under some unusual circumstance be increased to a high enough degree to be seen by the naked eye or physically alter material like the shroud? Are there any leads in the scientific literature of such a strange phenomenon existing?
Biophotons – The Light in Our Cells
From: http://transpersonal.de/mbischof/englisch/webbookeng.htm
What are biophotons ?
Biophotons, or ultraweak photon emissions of biological systems, are weak electromagnetic waves in the optical range of the spectrum – in other words: light. All living cells of plants, animals and human beings emit biophotons which cannot be seen by the naked eye but can be measured by special equipment developed by German researchers.
This light emission is an expression of the functional state of the living organism and its measurement therefore can be used to assess this state. Cancer cells and healthy cells of the same type, for instance, can be discriminated by typical differences in biophoton emission. […]
According to the biophoton theory developed on the base of these discoveries the biophoton light is stored in the cells of the organism – more precisely, in the DNA molecules of their nuclei – and a dynamic web of light constantly released and absorbed by the DNA may connect cell organelles, cells, tissues, and organs within the body and serve as the organism’s main communication network and as the principal regulating instance for all life processes. The processes of morphogenesis, growth, differentiation and regeneration are also explained by the structuring and regulating activity of the coherent biophoton field. The holographic biophoton field of the brain and the nervous system, and maybe even that of the whole organism, may also be basis of memory and other phenomena of consciousness, as postulated by neurophysiologist Karl Pribram an others. The consciousness-like coherence properties of the biophoton field are closely related to its base in the properties of the physical vacuum and indicate its possible role as an interface to the non-physical realms of mind, psyche and consciousness.
The discovery of biophoton emission also lends scientific support to some unconventional methods of healing based on concepts of homeostasis (self-regulation of the organism), such as various somatic therapies, homeopathy and acupuncture. The “ch’i” energy flowing in our bodies’ energy channels (meridians) which according to Traditional Chinese Medicine regulates our body functions may be related to node lines of the organism’s biophoton field. The “prana” of Indian Yoga physiology may be a similar regulating energy force that has a basis in weak, coherent electromagnetic biofields.
Background
First discovered in 1923 by Russian medical scientist Professor Alexander G.Gurvich (who named them “mitogenetic rays”) and in the 1930s widely researched in Europe and the USA, biophotons have been rediscovered and backed since the 1970s by ample experimental and theoretical evidence by European scientists. In 1974 German biophysicist Fritz-Albert Popp has proved their existence, their origin from the DNA and later their coherence (laser-like nature), and has developed biophoton theory to explain their possible biological role and the ways in which they may control biochemical processes, growth, differentiation etc. Popp’s biophoton theory leads to many startling insights into the life processes and may well provide one of the major elements of a future theory of life and holistic medical practice based on such an approach. The importance of the discovery has been confirmed by eminent scientists such as Herbert Froehlich and Nobel laureate Ilya Prigogine. Since 1992, the International Institute of Biophysics, a network of research laboratories in more than 10 countries, based in Germany, is coordinating research in this field which promises rapid development in the next decade. title: How do we know? No directionality of light.
post:
There is an alternative explanation: The artist would not make a portrait of Christ, but the imprint of a body on the canvas. The faces of Veronica circulating in the fourteenth Century were only painted portraits. Here the artist was more original. But he could not paint a real trace of a body in a cloth because the image would be distorted like this:http://sindone.weebly.com/uploads/1/2/2/0/1220953/8859260.jpg. Then he imagines invert the tones of a portrait in which the volume does not depend on the stray light, but making with darker shades the parts closest to the fabric and making clearer the farthest ones. Note that the same idea would be used in the Jumper and Jackson interpretation, obviously with another different conclusion. I have performed the same experiment taking a Renaissance portrait and it has turned this:  http://imageshack.us/photo/my-images/21/bonaiuti3ampliadocopia.jpg/ . And  Craig did this drawing directly with the same idea: https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-o9HJXZWP5RQ/UOp81Di1ZbI/AAAAAAAABMo/qpSoqkFQygI/s407/craig%20shroud.jpg . Not bad. 
What is nonsense is to compare the image of the Shroud with a Baroque portrait (Rembrandt) that models the volume with stray and hard contrasted light. Or more nonsense: I’ve seen in a movie Mr. Schumacher comparing the image of the Shroud with a Leonardo’s (three quarters view!) ink drawing. These are absolutely different pictorial techniques and concepts!

title: How do we know? No directionality of light.
post:
There’s no directionality in the image produced by the ancient pastime of brass rubbing. See this one of Sir Robert de Bures in 1310:

Note too the date. Forming images this way (which could be conceived as light/dark reversed negatives when compared with conventional artists’ portraits or modern photographs) was well known in the period immediately prior to the first public display of the TS in Lirey (1357). Note too the knightly connection.
One wonders why it is only (to my knowledge) Luigi Garlaschelli who has explored the capturing of a negative facsimile copy of a real person (or bas relief representation or parts thereof) via frottage (a rubbing method using dust as distinct from crayon but essentially the same technology, albeit with a final baking stage to fix the image onto fabric.
Lack of directionality implies imprinting by direct contact, instead of representation via the appearance when seen in reflected light. There would have been no mystique whatsoever attaching to negative images lacking directionality where your 14th century pilgrim was concerned. What the latter lacked to reward all those foot blisters was a Secondo Pia to show the dramatic effect that can be achieved by light/dark inversion, in which the positives, still with no directionality, look eerily like real people, or photographs thereof. Ring any bells? Should do – an entire peal thereof…
